intro: Papaver dubium subsp. stevenianum, commonly known as the Steven's poppy, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to southern Europe. It is characterized by its striking blue to violet flowers and hairy, lance-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The subspecies is distinguished by its slightly smaller flowers and more compact growth habit compared to the typical form of *Papaver dubium*.
